title: Jeremy Corbyn could back election 'before December 12th' if no deal is removed
text:

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has said he could back an election "before December 12th" if Boris Johnson removes the possibility of no deal from his Brexit bill.

So far Labour have refused to say they would vote for a general election on Monday with Mr Corbyn hinting that he wanted to know the EU's position on an extension.

But the party's MPs received instructions from the whips to abstain on the vote and were told they would not be punished if they voted against it.

Asked if he would support a poll if the EU decided to extend Britain's membership until January 31, Mr Corbyn told ITV's This Morning: "Providing the Prime Minister comes to Parliament on Monday and makes it absolutely clear he is going to make sure that there is no crash out - because his deal includes the possibility of a no-deal exit.

"He's going to have to do that because that's how Parliament works: we've got to hold him to account. I think a no-deal exit is very dangerous. If he comes on Monday and says that, OK."

(Image: Ken McKay/ITV/REX)

He added: "The 12th December date is really odd for many reasons. There’s lots of things very odd about that date." Asked whether that means he'll only back an election after December, he says: "Maybe before December 12th. I don’t know what the date is going to end up being

Urged by Richard Madeley to put Labour's case to the public in an election, Corbyn replies: "You know what, Richard? I think that’s what we’re going to be doing. And I’m going to enjoy it!"

The Labour leader said of Boris Johnson: "This is a very strange Prime Minister running parliament in a very strange way."

Meanwhile a meeting of EU27 ambassadors broke up without a decision on a potential delay with plans in place for a further meeting at the start of next week.
description: The Labour leader says he wants an election but he fears Boris Johnson could crash the UK out
